ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Blog posts and email discussion supplementation.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really appreciated the way I was able to write shorter papers in order to hone my style and voice. This is something that I don't always get time to focus on in my other classes--especially in final papers--but this has probably been the most valuable writing class I've ever taken because it focused on quality over quantity. In addition, the first and second drafts as well as feedback/workshop session were built into the syllabi so I got to spend time tweaking my work in a way I had not been able to before.

I developed much stronger writing skills -- from making pieces more dynamic and engaging to using more author's authority in my writing. I learned how to discuss art and make arguments about it in interesting and exciting ways. This included exploring the medium, content, and scale of artwork, among its other characteristics.

I really honed my writing skills, especially my voice as an author. I am used to writing analytically, but this course taught me how to write journalistically, which I thoroughly enjoyed! I also gained a lot of knowledge on contemporary artists.
Really great class teaching about how we speak about visual art. Weekly writing assignments are a page or two and help you learn how to write concise, interesting pieces about art/artists.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I like the blog posts each week, but I wish that they had been posted on Saturdays and that they had been included in the syllabus. Sometimes there were incongruencies between the professor's in class instructions, the syllabus PDF, and the Canvas submission prompt which was mostly a technical error and not a fault of the professor. This could be remedied with a few extra hours of organizational work before the semester and would save students a lot of hassle and potential confusion.

This course was one of the most well-organized and thoughtful courses I have taken during my time at Yale and I truly have very few suggestions. Everything -- from the material we studied to the assignments we completed to the time we spent in class -- was very effective, thought-provoking, and above all else, well-taught.
Overall, the course was really well organized and thorough. Sometimes I was overwhelmed with the amount of writing and reading, but Professor Spillane was so accommodating and understanding.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I appreciated the smaller class size, I think this is what made the virtual format so successful. I honestly can't think of anything, given the circumstances, that could have been improved in terms of remote learning.

I think Professor Spillane did a wonderful job of being aware of issues of Zoom fatigue and of ensuring that different teaching tactics she used were effective throughout the course. She was very open to feedback, and I found that the seminar teaching worked really well despite the constraints of a virtual format. While being in person would have been better (of course), I felt that the main group and breakout rooms worked well for discussion.

I think this course went quite well on the digital platform. The discussions were rich, the workshops were thorough, and Prof Spillane even organized a virtual Q&A with art critic, Roberta Smith. Overall, I think this course was very well adapted to the virtual formatno complaints!

There were a lot of assignments in different areas (video,reading,movies,blog posts) which was engaging and important, but just be aware that it is a lot of screen time. Good to break up and spread responsibilities over the week!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. If you are looking for a course that deals with writing about art in accessible formats, this is fantastic. You will also get your money's worth in terms of feedback and, as a result, improve exponentially as a writer.

Yes, absolutely. Professor Spillane is the most attentive and caring professor I have had during my time at Yale, and her investment in you and your progress as a student makes this class (and any class she teaches) a can't-miss. Plus, the course material is exceptionally interesting and is taught in a non-intimidating way even for those who do not have experience discussing art of any form.
Yes! I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who enjoys writing and is interested in art. You do not have to come in with experience, but I guarantee you will leave a much stronger writer.
Yes! It is a good amount of work but extremely rewarding- you walk away with tons of exposure to all kinds of contemporary art/artists and Professor Spillane is so knowledgeable/engaging.
